title: The Most Extraordinary Trial of William Palmer, for the Rugeley Poisonings, which lasted Twelve Days
author: Anonymous

quoteLast: , Mildred appeared, in answer to a summons, in the quiet-colored, pleasant drawing-room at Ascham, with its French windows giving on to the lawn, where some of the girls were playing hockey, not without cries. Her first view of Aunt Beatrice was a pleasant surprise.
title: The Invader: A Novel
author: Woods, Margaret L. (Margaret Louisa), 1856-1945

quoteLast: Running to Park Row, he found an assistant foreman of the _Sun_ composing-room enjoying his lemonade in Andy Horn’s restaurant. This man rounded up four or five printers, and they began setting up the story at 4 A.M. The _Sun_ had a complete and exclusive story, and twenty thousand copies were sold of Fitzgerald’s extra.
title: The Story of the Sun: New York, 1833-1918
author: O'Brien, Frank Michael, 1875-; Mitchell, Edward Page, 1852-1927 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Edwin entered somewhat furtively, and as it were guiltily, though in Crown Square and the streets and the other squares visible therefrom, not a soul could be seen.  The illuminated clock of the Old Town Hall at the top of the square showed
quoteLast: .  Immediately within the door began a new, very long and rather mean staircase, with which Edwin was acquainted.  He closed the door, shutting out the light and the town, and struck a match in the empty building.
title: These Twain
author: Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931

quoteLast: a three-mast ship was hailed to larboard.
title: A Floating City, and The Blockade Runners
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

title: Lippincott's Magazine of Popular Literature and Science, Vol. 26, November, 1880
author: Various

quoteLast: elevated train from the Harlem bridge was awake for once. The sleeper is the last car in the train, and has its own set that snores nightly in the same seats, grunts with the fixed inhospitality of the commuter at the intrusion of a stranger, and is on terms with Conrad, the German conductor, who knows each one of his passengers and wakes him up at his station. The sleeper is unique.
title: Out of Mulberry Street: Stories of Tenement life in New York City
author: Riis, Jacob A. (Jacob August), 1849-1914

quoteLast: elevated train from the Harlem bridge was awake for once. The sleeper is unique.
title: Children of the Tenements
author: Riis, Jacob A. (Jacob August), 1849-1914; Relyea, C. M. (Charles M.), 1863-1932 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: In the early hours of that day a heavy enemy bombardment presaged the coming attack. At
quoteLast: the South African Battalion, which had been taken over on the 24th by Lieutenant-Colonel Bamford, was warned to be ready to move at fifteen minutes’ notice. At 5 a.m. von Armin attacked with nine divisions, five of which were fresh. His purpose was to capture Kemmel by a direct assault on the French, and by a simultaneous attack on the British right south of Wytschaete to turn their flank and separate the two forces. At first he seemed about to succeed.
title: The history of the South African forces in France
author: Buchan, John, 1875-1940

title: Lippincott's Magazine of Popular Literature and Science, Vol. 26, November, 1880
